(Traducción al español abajo)

How to drown a good game into disgrace.

Having the original Colin McRae Rally 2.0 since it came out, all I expected was to be able to play it fully in my actual machine without learning rocket science. Well, I have to recognize that has been achieved. You can play it... at least the parts you can...

Megabazillion tracks... errr nope: The original game brings us 9 countries, (Kenia, Finland, UK, Sweden, Australia, Japan, Corsica, Greece and Italy) each with twelve stages. This rip only brings Australia, Corsica and Italy. By now, The game duration's been cut to a third.

Megabazillion rally cars... errr neither: The original game places us behind the wheel of 24 rally cars, counting WRC, B group and various paint schemes. Here there are ONLY FOUR STINKY CARS. Content reduced to a fifth.

Then, the controls. I'll agree Colin McRae wasn't the most realistic rally game in history (we have RBR for that), but at least you can figure out what is driving a WRC. Here, the controls are almost random. The car cuts gas in the middle of a straight without any reason at all, and the turns are divided into two: you did it or you didn't (There's no way to negotiate a drift)... Basically, I found out that I can't drive the car as I want (as in the original), but instead I have to learn how the game wants me to drive it.

And then, the graphics... well, even worse than the original (the internal view is worth a shot, don't miss it), plus the scenary has been cut to a size that looks more like you're playing Gran Turismo 1.

In a nutshell, don't set your hopes any high: It's an awful port, ripped everywhere, and almost unplayable.

Colin McRae Rally

You hear that name and instantly awesome true Rally experiences come to mind. Harsh terrain, realistic and believable damage to your car as you make stupid mistakes, and a fairly competitive AI that makes it a nice challenge all-in-all.

That isn't this game. This game is a mobile port. It isn't (at all) what it tries to advertise itself as. Handling is simplified, damage is merely cosmetic at best, the terrain looks horrible. Remastered is a term many low-resolution games use these days to try and bring these experiences to the modern PC, but Colin McRae Rally doesn't manage to do any of it.

It lacks features that previous games in the series. You can't customize your car's behavior before a stage. Repairs are fairly unneeded as they don't impact gameplay, and fixing the engine" costs the same amount of time as fixing the "suspension" or "wheels".

There isn't much else to say. This game was trading on good memories of the Colin McRae series and it's just a cash grab. It's lame

reviewText:
Like many others, I bought this game expecting a re-released version of the original with some graphics updates and without the hassle of getting an old copy to run on modern hardware. This is not that game.

What we have instead is a stripped-down version with less cars, fewer stages and fewer set-up/repair options which was previously released for mobile devices. Between purchase and writing this review the store description has been updated to reflect this, but it still leaves a faint glimmer of hope that this might be something better. Don't be under any illusions  - you're paying to play the mobile version with better controls on a bigger screen.

In fairness to Codemasters, this is at least a competent driving game. The cars handle at least as well as in the original, with noticeable changes between surfaces. Car damage does affect performance, but the scaled-back repair interface takes away most of the decisions in choosing what to fix between stages. There are only four cars available to drive (three of which must be unlocked by completing events), but they recreated as well as possible in the engine.

Ultimately though, I can't recommend this. It may only be £4.99, but that still feels expensive for a cut-down version of a ten-year-old game. You would be better-off spending your money on a copy of the original on ebay and taking the time to get it working

I've gone for a tentative Yes here, despite me kind of only half liking it. If you buy it and try it, you're getting a useful insight into mobile gaming ported to PC. You're also getting one of a few sparse rally games available for PC these days, and for that, it does hold some value. Just make sure you buy it cheap!
I had already bought this on Android and it didn't last long before I deleted it. In hindsight I do wonder if I'd merely missed a config screen allowing you to adjust sensitivity, and in the case of PC, dead zone too.  For my first couple of goes on PC, it was horrible with a 50% deadzone meter and maximum sensitivity. The car would barely turn for most of the stick's travel, then suddeny lurch, makign it twitchy an unresponsive at the same time. Wholly unpleasant. However, step the deadzone down to a few notches off minimum, and reduce the sensitivity to about 35% and it's a different animal; it feels to control much better.

reviewText:
Before you buy this game you need to realise that this is not a full HD remake of Colin Mcrae Rally 2.0 but a port of the mobile phone version, which contains far less content. 3 different rally zones, Australia, Greece and Corsica. It also only has 4 drivable cars, the Ford Focus, Subaru Impreza, Mitsubishi Lancer Evolution and the Lanica Stratos. Whether more tracks and cars will become available later down the line, I don’t know.

The menu design is rather clunky and is clearly designed for a touch screen device and there is no tuning section for your car and no replays after each race. There is however a section for repairing your car after 2 rally stages although as far as I can see the damage on your car does little to how you perform during a race.

As for the racing the controls are okay, the graphics are also okay however some of the textures such as the walls can look very ugly, alot of the sprites also look fairly blend eg. Crowd members and trees. To get round this there is quite a bit of motion blur which does make the game look smoother at times.

The pyhsics of the game are also okay but not great. There is some visual damage to your car when you hit objects, but this could be improved massively. There are also inconsistences in the track I found myself getting caught on flat bits of land and getting flung up into the air with no real reason.

Finally the speed, when I first started the game I thought I hadn't set my car up correct because it seemed so slow. In many rally cars you find yourself in constant battle to keep the car under control, however here you can hold down the gas/acceleration button for the majority of the time without having many issues.

So my thoughts this game is okay at best, but it could of been more, should of been more. It should have brought back the old school Colin Mcrae Rally 2.0 memories. But this game simply doesn't live up to that title and that’s a shame.

reviewText:
Usually, when I write some impressions I always speak about what the game is all about instead of what it could have been. However, in a rally game with Colin McRae in the title it’s a bit hard to not see the true potential that has gone to waste. The description of the origin of the game tell no lies, it’s a port of a mobile game so we are aware of what we can expect in terms of visuals and weather effects, sound, and so on. However, there is some information that not only I do not agree but I also find it to be a bit misleading.

The description of the game mentions different types of surfaces. While this may be true, aside of road and off-road I didn’t see any other variations. There is no mud, no heavy dust, no snow or wet tracks giving you a very limited window when it comes to variety. Speaking of variety, the number of cars you can drive is really small, only four are available. This is a very low number for a rally game and to make it worst you need to unlock them if you want to race with them in the championship. The four cars are the Ford Focus, Subaru Impreza, the classic Lancia Stratos and the Mitsubishi Lancer Evolution VI. The sound is as important for me as the visuals and if you are a racing fan you will want to have those crazy sound engines screaming for the next shift but once again you can’t expect such thing in this game, which is fine for a mobile port but insufficient for a PC game.

In the end I played the game and got most of it, however there is not much to see and do which makes you search for better alternatives. The final line from the Store description ends with a bang but I’m afraid to be a really misleading sentence. It says “The Classic Rally Experience Races on PC and Mac” and I couldn’t agree less. This is not true at all no matter how big or small you are into racing games.

reviewText:
This is not a rally simulation. There are not a ton of cars or tracks. This is a port of the mobile game which is a low budget arcade racer. If you are okay with all of that then you will most likely enjoy this game.

- The graphics are outdated but get the job done. A lot of the assets seem to be taken straight from the old CMR games.
- The audio is decent. Most of the audio seems to be from the old CMR games as well.
- The physics are extremely arcadey. The cars are pretty slippery but in a fun way.
- The AI drivers (Colin McRae specifically) seem to be immune to car damage. Always going full speed while you're car is chugging along. This is more noticeable towards the end of the game because there are more endurance events. It is all about damage management while going as fast as possible.

I really enjoyed this game and would recommend it to arcade race fans and rally fans. I had no idea this was a mobile port until I was halfway through. That didn't stop it from being fun.

There are a ton of terrible racing games on Steam that cost much more than this, I'm not sure why people are so down on it. For $6.99 I have little to complain about.

reviewText:
This is a good game, but there are few things you have to consider when you are up to buy it.
It seems to be mostly based upon Colin McRae Rally 2.0, and seems to be ported version from mobile device.

General observations:
- Quite a simple graphics judged by today expectations (still found of sufficient level to my mind). Looks like CMR2.0 with modern processing effects applied.
- Quite an accurate car models of real vehicles
- Decent physical model with unique behaviour for each vehicle
- Each car seems to have it's own specific durability level of each system and tends to receive specific damage depending on your driving style

In comparions with CMR2.0 some content is removed:
- less cars avaliable
- no tuning
- simplified repairs
- less rallies (no Finland, Sweden, Kenya and England)
- no duel stages at the end of each rally
- no weather and night stages
- rallies are shorter (6 stages per rally max)
- less camera modes
- no arcade mode
- much less unlockable content
I used to be very found of CMR series and especially of 2.0, but still I can make some mistakes in my comparison cause it was long ago when I used to play it.

Summary:
Don't take it as one of CMR istallments, but consider it to be separate game of more arcade style.
Would siut casual players, those who llooks for CMR2.0 nostalgie sessions, people infamiliar with CMR series and looking for arcade with real vehicles with more or less realistic behavior.
Will fail to meet your expectations if you are looking for something in line with established CMR experience.

Anyway I'd still recommend this game as a good fun.

reviewText: Colin McRae Rally is an arcade-style offroad racing game, where you can drive different offroad racers in a variety of circuits and tournaments. Now, I compare all racing games to Gran Turismo 2, which is in my humble opinion, the best racing sim I have ever played. It reminds me of the arcade play of Gran Turismo 2, where you could drive cars like the Lancer Evo on dirt tracks, against a second player or versus computer drivers; However, with Colin McRae Rally, you are going up against computer players times, rather than the actual cars on the track. I think this takes away from the realism of the game, because you don't have other drivers as obstacles to conquer and overcome, it's all about time instead. Visually, the game is so-so, but the cars are pretty detailed. There doesn't appear to be a lot of customization. In all, I wasn't overly impressed with the game, though it isn't exactly a dumpster fire either. It skates by, but there are other racing games out there which would be better.

reviewText:
I've changed my review after playing this game again Months later. I don't think it's *as* bad as I originally wrote but it just doesn't stand up all that well next to more modern PC titles. Probably because it was intended as a mobile game.

It's totally playable and kind of addictive once you get into it. For the price, I think it's OK but just don't expect anything amazing. You can expect arcade rally .. closer to Sega Rally than Colin McRae .. I just wish it didn't have McRae's name on, because I think we all expected a modern remake closer to something like CM3 based on the original content. Honestly, if this was released in 1999 it'd be awesome, but as a modern PC racing title by a major development company like Codemasters it seems like an odd decision to release something for PC that clearly wasn't meant to be.

The graphics are nice enough.. no problems there. Not great, but nice enough.

UI is ugly and very basic. I can see what they tried to do (to try to recreate the old minimalist CMR2 interface) but it's clumsy and there's no polish to make it all feel nice like the original. It just feels like they took some screengrabs from the original and slapped them onto the screen.

At the end of the day, it's hard to judge this as a PC game. This is a mobile game converted to PC .. as in, they opened up the source files in Unity, changed the target build to PC from iOS, hit publish and went to lunch.. at least, that's what it seems like. Sure, they turned on the bloom filter and enabled soft shadows but come on, that's about 10 minutes work .. it's the mobile version with the least amount of effort to convert to PC.

If I clear my mind of Colin McRae Rally completely, I can enjoy this game for what it is - a pretty simplistic arcade style rally game. Problem is that Dirt1,2,3 and Dirt Rally have all happened since then and this is left looking really dated.

reviewText:
If you want a nostalgic rally game, or something to fill in time between DiRT releases, this is defintely a good buy. Otherwise, don't buy it and you might as well stop reading here.

As a whole game, it barely stands up with a few glitches in places, and some very repetitive rally stages (I've only found there to be 3 different countries so far). But the experience from this game is more of a reason to buy it.

Essentially it feels like the rally games from 10 years ago (partly because it is) but the touch-ups in the remake allow it to feel and look how it does in your memory. This game does what it sets out to perfectly, it lets you relive the old games, without too many of the hassles involved in installing and setting up to work with controllers.

As for the actual gameplay, the difficulty level is fairly easy and all the competitors times are pre-determined. The stage progress bar up the top (straight from the old rally games) bears no reference to whats happening on the track for your competitors, and only shows average speed of the lead CPU (Colin Mcrae in every race).

When driving, you get the familar pace notes, although they are mostly accurate, relying on them too heavily will cause an accident. Things like sudden hairpins, jumps immediately before corners, and the pace notes only being 30-70m ahead of you make for some very reaction oriented driving (especially in Australia...).

Damage is taken fairly easily in the cars, with even crash free stages short causing quite severe damage by the time you get in for repairs, making the 30 minutes for repairs quite strategic. When you crash (you will), the damage to power and suspension is the most noticeable, followed by the wheels, making you have to dynamically change driving styles mid-race (momentum is key with a ruined engine.)

If you're expecting a fully fledged game, that will give you an engaging storyline, or even a new experience, don't buy this game. If you're after a relaxed drive down memory lane, and this game is on sale, I highly recommend it.

Pros -
Takes you back to the rally games of ten years ago.
Works flawlessly with Xbox 360 Controller.
More emphasis on better driving, rather than speed.
Damage and repairs is a nice change.

Cons -
Invisible walls just of the edge of the track in some places.
Pace notes not always accurate or timely.
I crashed in the middle of the road, into the road at one point.
Rolling the car doesn't result in immediate car reset.
Not much variety in rally stages.

When this game first appeared on steam it was described as an HD remake of Colin McRae Rally 2.0 and I decided to buy it as soon as it was on sale. By the time it was on sale it was apparent that this was in fact a PC port of the mobile game based upon Colin McRae Rally 2.0 and it had loads of negative reviews. My first thought when I started the game was isn't this supposed to have updated graphics? After a look at screen shots of the original I could see the graphics have been updated but it still doesn't look great. I realised at this point that this game does not just need to measure up to the original but to the idealised version in my head coloured by years of nostalgia.

To be fair it did have some aspects that lived up to my expectations. The overall driving mechanics are excellent fun (apart from the occasional collision detection glitch that just stops your car). It also has the great damage management aspects of the original what has been lacking from many of more recent dirt games.

I am however still going to give this a thumbs down because they have cut so much out in comparison to the original it is not worth it. Most of the cars are gone, most of the tracks are gone, there are no different liveries, no different weather conditions, the car set up is gone and the detailed in car view is gone.

reviewText:
When this game first appeared on steam it was described as an HD remake of Colin McRae Rally 2.0 and I decided to buy it as soon as it was on sale. By the time it was on sale it was apparent that this was in fact a PC port of the mobile game based upon Colin McRae Rally 2.0 and it had loads of negative reviews. In the end I still bought it because even if it is a cut down version I still wanted to play it to relive the fond memories of the original game.

My first thought when I started the game was isn't this supposed to have updated graphics? After a look at screen shots of the original I could see the graphics have been updated but it still doesn't look great. I realised at this point that this game does not just need to measure up to the original but to the idealised version in my head coloured by years of nostalgia.

To be fair it did have some aspects that lived up to my expectations. The overall driving mechanics are excellent fun (apart from the occasional collision detection glitch that just stops your car). It also has the great damage management aspects of the original what has been lacking from many of more recent dirt games.

I am however still going to give this a thumbs down because they have cut so much out in comparison to the original it is not worth it. Most of the cars are gone, most of the tracks are gone, there are no different liveries, no different weather conditions, the car set up is gone and the detailed in car view is gone.

reviewText:
Colin McRae Rally 2.0 was my childhood rally game back in the PS1 days.

This remaster/remake is not the same as the original from 2000.

Pros:
- HD graphics.
- Good old Nicky Grist.
- Steam backgrounds.
- Trading Cards.

Cons:
- Only 4 cars. (Original PS1/PC game from 2000 - 23 cars)
- Only 3 countries. (Original - 8 countries)
- Physics.
- Mobile port. (Android/iOS game which was ported to Steam)
- Can't change MPH (Imperial) to KMH (Metric).

As a massive fan of Colin McRae Rally series in general, this game is a tough one to recommend.

Sure, it's a remake of the original.. but it's seriously lacking content.

Pro tip: Play the original game on your PC or use a PS1 emulator. You'll notice a huge difference between the original and the remake.

reviewText:
tl;dr: THIS IS NOT A REMASTER OF THE ORIGINAL PC VERSION. THIS IS A PORT OF A MOBILE GAME. DO NOT BUY!

so, the game sucks in almost every aspect, here's why:

Graphic: probably the only good thing in this game. the nostalgia feeling is there, the game looks really like the old one, althought it has been rewritten in Unity. It uses most of the original assets and adds some realtime shadows, motion blur and sligthly better car models

Sound: awful. the car's sound is flat and boring. co-pilot voice has just few lines and also has bad timing causing them to be played too late or overlap each other

Tracks: 6 rallies in 3 countries (Australia, Greece, France) spanning over 12 stages each (althought some of them are reversed). the tracks come from from the original game (so they're good) but they have been slightly modified to adapt to a mobile game: moslty, the road has been widen, but also, all the surface react the same way, there's no difference between tarmac and grass.

Cars: only 4 cars. Ford Focus, Subaru Impreza '99, Lancer Evolution VI, Lancia Delta. the first tree handle the same way, while the fourth outperform each of the other in every way speed, accelleration and handling (which is completly unrealistic)

Controls: bad. since is a mobile port, the game is not designed to take analogic input, so wether you're using a keyboard or a gamepad the experience is the same. the game also supports steering wheels, mine didn't work and i found complains on the forum that the steering feels digital even with the wheel. it's also very difficult to assign buttons.

Physics: bad, very bad. you can clearly feel that the game was designed for mobile devices, the handling is very simple and braking is un-necessary. impacts are broken wheter you impact perpendicularly or just scracth something the result is the same: the car stops. it also happens to crash into invisible walls in the middle of the track or your car start to bounce around for no reason (especially the Stratos)

Damage: broken. the car get damage even if you drive safely and slowly on a tarmac road. I would not be surpirsed if in the mobile version you have to wait for the car to get repaired or pay to repair it.

Game modes: you can race on a single stage, a whole rally or a championship. the career is made of various championship, the first 6 just made of the 6 available rallies, the others mix the rallies in various ways but not the stages, so you'll have to do the same stages in the same order over and over again. the original game was similar but with different car classes and over 12 countries.

AI: one of the worst example of the rubber-band effect ever seen in a game, and it's also way too easy completly lacking any challenge.


this game it's a scam, they tried to make money on the nostalgia of the players with a very bad port of a very bad mobile game. AVOID even if it's free
